utterances: And before I let you go, I want you to talk to us a bit about the generation's project.
My daughter and I were talking about a generation's project because my mother sings as well.
You've heard me sing, now you've heard Paris sing, you've heard my daughter sing with Sounds of Blackness, and my sister, Ms. Marie Graham, she also was a part of Sounds of Blackness.
She will be a part of this generation project and we want you to know that my mother, Shirley Bennett, can sing a Mahalia Jackson song that will make you cringe in your shoes.
And we want to take it all over the world to let people know about the ability and the gift to sing a whole gamut of African-American music as a whole family.
Before we let you go, Ann, like so many -- we just had Roberta Flack on, decided hey, you know, to be healthy, I'm gonna lose some of this weight.
I understand you've lost over a 100 pounds.
I absolutely did.
In January of 2005, I stayed in intensive care for about six days with congestive heart failure.
And, at that point, I realized that I could not really, really serve my family or God in that condition with my health out of control and my doctor referred me to have this surgery.
I was very, very nervous about it, but I prayed and I felt like it was the right thing to do.
I lost 129 pounds and I'm definitely striving to keep it off so that I will be able to be around for Paris' great success and also to be around to finish the ministry that God has called me to.
Well, that is so wonderful.
Congratulations on that, and whether it's...
Thank you.
And whether it's the solo success you've had on the secular side with great songs like ""I'm Still Wearing Your Name,"" which you wore out.
Thank you.
Or anybody who can stand there and sing with Al Green and ""Put it on Paper"" and know that you're holding your own, you gotta do what you gotta do.
But...
Oh absolutely.
...as you say, you've gone back to your roots for this project.
Ann Nesby, we want to thank you for being a part of the show.
Thank you.

There's no hiding the Democrats' excitement about finally getting control of Congress.
It's been 12 years, after all.
And so far, they've been talking a lot about overhauling ethics and raising the minimum wage and curbing deficits.
What they haven't said much about yet, though, is the War in Iraq, as NPR's David Welna reports from the Capitol.
Well, that was great.
We have heard over and over that part of the shock Thursday was that things like this don't happen in a small town like Roseburg.
Certainly, people were rattled.
Obviously, lots of kids are scared.
Twenty-six-year-old Roseburg native Megan Tollefson is not.
And especially after seeing our law enforcement do what they did in less than 10 minutes, I don't think there's anything to worry about.
I don't think there's any reason to hole up.
But even out in the open, unafraid, Tollefson, like so many, has questions for a dead gunman.
Why?
Why did you feel the need to be selfish about it and do it the way you did do it instead of seeking help, getting some kind of help to figure out what was wrong with yourself?
Ian Mercer is asking the same questions about his son, who killed himself at the end of his rampage at UCC.

In a CNN interview from his home in California, British-born Mercer said he had a harmonious relationship with his son, but hadn't seen him since Chris Harper-Mercer moved to Oregon with his mother several years ago.
In the interviewer, Ian Mercer said he was stunned by his son's reported arsenal seized by authorities after the attack.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I'm not trying to say that to blame for what happened, but if Chris had not been able to get a hold of 13 guns, it wouldn't have happened.
Officials said Saturday the number actually was 14 after discovering another pistol in Chris Harper-Mercer's apartment.
It was also announced an FBI behavioral analyst team has arrived to help figure out the why of the attack.
Meanwhile, the Umpqua Community College campus reopens Monday.
Classes resume a week later.
Tom Goldman, NPR News, Roseburg, Ore.
U.S.
and Chinese officials have been trading criticisms for the past few weeks over China's building on disputed islands in the South China Sea.
The two countries' military ships and planes have cautiously maneuvered around each other.
This weekend, the two sides faced each other at a security forum in Singapore.
NPR's Anthony Kuhn reports from Beijing that there are no clear answers in sight to this complex regional dispute.
But for now, both sides appear to have kept it from escalating into direct conflict.
Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter spoke to military officials and analysts gathered at the Shangri-La Dialogue security forum.
Carter called for all parties in the dispute to stop building on and militarizing the disputed islands.
But he was especially critical of China.
(SOUNDBITE OF 2015 SHANGRI-LA DIALOGUE)

With its actions in the South China Sea, China is out of step with both the international rules and norms that underscore the Asia Pacific security architecture and the regional consensus that favors diplomacy and opposes coercion.
He added that building on the reefs would not help China to stake its claim to them.
Later, a member of the Chinese military delegation took the floor.
(SOUNDBITE OF 2015 SHANGRI-LA DIALOGUE)
